Strat wise, here's a wall of text from Morgan Stanley.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Stop Brexit and put a halt to crony capitalism!
BE11:29am

Today Prime Minister May proposed Parliamentary votes on customs and a referendum, as concessions to get a majority for her deal. But we think the deal is still unlikely to pass, and that agreement on the way forward will require a new political process. Closing the gap?: PM May proposed changes today aimed at creating a crossparty majority. In particular, there was an offer of Parliamentary votes on a temporary customs union until the next general election and on a second referendum. Not quite: We think this doesn't change the parliamentary maths. Labour said they will not support a deal without a binding commitment on a permanent customs union – apparently, this is not on offer. And second referendum supporters will likely only support the deal if it makes Brexit dependent on the referendum's outcome – but it appears this is also not on offer. Plus, we think any new support from Labour MPs who support Brexit is likely to be offset by reduced support from those Conservative MPs who would prefer a WTO Brexit under a new leader. A more binary Brexit: Without cross-party agreement, we do not expect the Brexit deal to pass. If parliament rejects the deal a fourth time, we think a political process will be needed to decide the way forward. We see a more binary outcome, with a lower probability of a soft Brexit (30%), and a higher probability of either a hard Brexit (25%) or Remain (45%).

nightingale20201 1stLt. Fletcher ......BBC Nightsnight last night did a good comparison between the demise of Jamie's Kitchen and Brit Steel...watch that on the iplayer if interested...
BE11:31am

The distribution across potential outturns
is still relatively flat, which is jargon for “anything could happen”. But a base case is coming into view, and is
worth articulating to aid thinking even if unlikely to be correct. That runs broadly as follows: after a summer
dominated by the question of the Conservative leadership Boris Johnson becomes PM in early September on a
“no deal if we have to” platform. The EU refuses his central objective of removing the backstop from the
Withdrawal agreement. The Commons begins the process of legislating to force Johnson to seek an Article 50
extension, and Johnson calls a general election seeking a mandate for his approach. The UK and EU agree to
extend Article 50 to end December to allow time for the general election to take place and for discussions to
follow it.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

We have written on multiple occasions in the past that the road to a potential “no deal” Brexit begins with the
resignation of PM May. Even with the current composition of the UK House of Commons, we have worried
whether it would be assertive enough to prevent a new Brixeteer PM pursuing that course, particularly during
the “honeymoon” period when such a leader first comes into office. At this time of writing, that appears to be
exactly where we are headed. Boris Johnson has a big lead in polls of Conservative members, and looks like he
could be named as Conservative leader at some point in late August or September. The Conservative Party
conference will be a coronation for the new leader running September 29th-October 3rd, and we then face an
Article 50 deadline at the end of October.
In the words of former Conservative chief whip Andrew Mitchell, the leadership is “Boris’s to lose”. Those
vying for the leadership will be seeking the support of a Conservative membership that has become increasingly
convinced of the correctness of Brexit and willing to proceed via “no deal”. There is a clear risk (or even
likelihood) that statements made by leadership candidates to play to that audience will antagonize the EU and
reduce the already limited space for negotiation between the two sides. It is not difficult to imagine the new
leader making a strident commitment to leave the EU on October 31st during the campaign, with or without a
deal being in place. By extension, it is not difficult to imagine one or more EU leaders responding to a bellicose
turn in UK rhetoric by stating that they will not support a further extension of Article 50. And we doubt a
change in PM alone would make the EU willing to reconsider the Irish backstop in the Withdrawal Agreement.
We agree with what appears to be the consensus opinion that it is more likely than not that the Commons would
act to prevent a “no deal” Brexit occurring. In our view, however, that call is closer than most appear to realize.
It is worth remembering that the Cooper-Letwin bill instructing the PM to seek an extension passed by only a
single vote. The possibility of the administration filibustering and delaying the passage of any such legislation
through the House of Lords could be relevant if available time running up to the end October deadline is tight.
In those circumstances the only way to ensure an extension is sought (or Article 50 is revoked if necessary)
could be for MPs to vote no-confidence in the government, and replace it with an administration prepared to
take that action.

BE11:31am

In the event that Boris Johnson wins a leadership contest it is likely a number of Conservative MPs will resign
the Party whip and either sit as independent MPs or join Change UK. Indeed, it is possible that Johnson could
lose the ability to reliably command a majority in the Commons on non-Brexit issues through this route.
However, these MPs are likely to lose their seats in any early election. Should they vote no-confidence in the
government, any “replacement” administration put in place to avoid “no deal” may not be in office for very
long. Moreover, Conservative MPs who vote against the policies of the newly elected leader would likely face
the threat of subsequent deselection by their local party associations. As a result, we could imagine votes of noconfidence
prompted by an attempt to force a “no deal” Brexit being close.

BE11:31am

As best as we can tell, the coming leadership contest would be the first in which the Party membership will
select both a leader and a PM without a general election intervening. That will raise some awkward questions
about legitimacy and plausibly a latent inclination for the new PM to seek a broader mandate. An ability of the
Commons to frustrate the new PM’s “no deal” policy would be an ever stronger motivation to seek a new
majority. If the new Conservative leader is able to unite “Leavers” behind them, Conservative poll ratings are
likely to rise. It is not difficult to imagine the “remain” vote being split between a Labour party offering a
second referendum, and a Change UK-Liberal Democrat alliance actively seeking to reverse the Brexit decision.
As much as an election is something the Conservatives have wanted to avoid under Theresa May given the
experience of 2017, our expectation is that it will look a less daunting (if not entirely palatable) prospect as the
year progresses. While backing a second referendum could be another way to resolve the political impasse,
legislating for that would be much more time-consuming than holding a general election, and less likely to be
supported by Brexiteers.

Strikingly, its own surveys show that a record balance of households surveyed has no idea where interest rates are heading over the next 12 months

11:36 am
BE11:36am

We identify five key issues:
o The MPC’s (Monetary Policy Committee) guidance on the path of the bank rate – the BoE’s primary monetary policy tool – and the underlying “conditioning”
assumptions that go into its quarterly forecasts are excessively complicated and are unnecessary to achieve the BoE’s mandate.
o By raising rates far more slowly than its consistently hawkish forward guidance signalled, the BoE has weakened the link between its communications and actions.
o The BoE has been excessively timid with its policy normalisation given the healthy UK economic fundamentals.
o With Brexit, the BoE has departed from its standard approach of incorporating government policy into its forecasts and policy decisions. Instead, it has put too much emphasis on potential Brexit scenarios – especially to the downside.
o Inflation expectations are no longer well anchored and have risen sharply since the Brexit vote. Unless the BoE takes steps to re-anchor inflation expectations, its capacity to look through future temporary inflationary shocks could be constrained.

BE11:37am

The BoE’s fading ability to shape expectations has three key negative implications:
1) It raises the risks that markets get caught out by future policy changes; 2) The BoE will get less bang for its buck for a given policy change in the future; and
3) Its ability to look through transitory exogenous inflation shocks is diminished.
● The BoE should address the problems with its current monetary policy framework.
It should simplify its forward guidance and the conditioning assumptions for its forecasts. In light of Brexit developments, the BoE should make its reaction function more transparent. Any steps the BoE can take to strengthen the link between its actions and words should be encouraged.

FATDAZ @1st LT my thoughts exactly we see to be happy to ignore national security and security of supply at times like this

CMD's ongoing. Here's the pre-event stuff.

BE11:43am

Jefferies:

11:43 am
BE11:43am

In-line FY18/19 results reflected a 26% drop in operating profit, driven by deteriorating revenue trends, increasing cost pressures and limited productivity improvements. The dividend will be cut by 40% to

15p (6.5% yield), and in line with our earlier estimates. FY19/20E guidance is in line with consensus, reflecting a ramp-up in the cost avoidance run-rate. A new strategic plan will be presented at CMD today, targeting a profitability recovery longer-term.

BE11:44am

Nah, that doesn't say a whole lot. Have Goldman.

BE11:44am

UKPIL mail volumes declined 8% for FY2018/19, marking an acceleration compared to previous years (driven in our view by the weaker economic growth/business confidence in the UK and effects of the GDPR regulations). Parcels volumes showed a strong 8% volume growth, with a 7% revenue growth, implying a 1% negative price/mix effect (with a better price/mix effect than most European postal companies). The company delivered £107mn of cost avoidance (versus targets of £100mn), with a 0.9% productivity growth (1.9% in the second half): we think that the productivity acceleration is positive news after productivity growth stalled earlier in the year. GLS reported a contraction in margins, delivering 6.1% EBIT margins for the year (broadly anticipated by consensus) due to cost pressure, while revenues grew by 8%.

Soundbuy Thought margins in parcels were under pressure...............and folk thought RMG was sold on the cheap............
simple simon Babcock please if time permits
11:45 am
BE11:45am

In terms of short and medium term guidance, the company expects five to seven percent mail volume decline for 2019-20 (excluding elections mailings), and a return to four to six percent mail volume decline over the medium term. In UK parcels, it targets 4-5% volume growth, but with over 5% revenue growth (signalling, in our view, a positive focus on yield management). Royal Mail is targeting to invest £1.8bn over five years in the UK Postal service, including additional investments to fund the UK turnaround. Overall, for its UK operations, Royal Mail is targeting a 4% operating profit margin for 2021-22 and 5% operating profit margin for 2023-24. For its international parcels business, GLS it is targeting 6-7% operating profit margins per annum, with an ongoing focus in B2B and only selective growth in B2C.

BE11:45am

Overall, we see the headline numbers as ambitious, as they would imply a significant (greater than 50%) growth in operating profits over the next four years (FY20-FY24) which could make it an attractive investment case should they deliver given recent share price weakness. While we believe that the increased focus in parcels is a welcome development (and should contribute to margin expansion), another key driver of profits will be the productivity growth at the company where there have been some disappointments in the recent past. As such, our first impression is that we believe that the market might want to see the first evidence of the turnaround (which could potentially unlock significant value at the company), before giving the company credit for it.

BE11:46am

Is it extraordinary that Royal Mail's given volume, revenue and margin guidance out to 2024?

The FY19 finals in line, with PBT +1% to £517.9m. However, FY20 forecasts reduced by 7% (EPS 73.7p vs 78.9p previously), primarily reflecting the weakness in short-cycle contracts. Another downgrade to estimates in a long series of downgrades. It is currently difficult to envisage a catalyst to positively rerate the shares, therefore despite the shares trading on only 6.9x FY20E EPS, we lower our recommendation to Hold (from Add) with a revised target price of 461p (was 578p).

Bluesky21 Woodford #3 shareholder at Babcock, with 5%
BE11:55am

PBT +1% to £517.9m (PHe £518.3m, consensus £519.1m).
EPS +1% to 84.0p (PHe 83.7p, consensus 83.8p). DPS +2% to 30.0p. Revenue declined by 3.8% (down 1.9% organic at CER, down 1.0% excluding exits) to £5,160.6m as result of the disposal/exits from small non-core businesses and lower activity levels in the short cycle parts of the business. EBITA +1% to £588.4m. 11.4% margin ahead of FY18’s 10.9%, reflecting the increased contribution from the Holdfast (RSME) JV, good contract performance and the exit of low margin businesses. Combined order book and pipeline flat at £31bn. Exceptionals charges totalled £160.8m (£26m net cash cost, excluding pensions): reshaping of the oil & gas business (asset impairment £39.0m, onerous lease provisions £42.1m), exits & disposals (£6.6m), and rightsizing capacity across sectors (£42.4m), EU exit tax charge (£10.0m) and GMP equalisation and bulk transfer charge (£30.7m).

FATDAZ @Supposed to be working that is a good point re solvency II

Tony Scott @Bluesky- Woodford seems to have the faecal touch at the moment...
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian If people could envisage a catalyst the shares wouldn't be as cheap.
Bluesky21 He is a good indicator for where value traps are
BE11:55am

Forecasts reduced by 7%. PHe FY20E PBT was £489.9m (EPS 78.9p) vs consensus £487.2m (78.2p). Babcock now expects revenue of c£4.9bn, an EBITA margin of between 10.7% and 11.0% (PHe 11.3%) and EBITA in the range of £515m to £535m (PHe £557.4m). Guidance reflects the previously highlighted step-downs and the current market conditions, including the weakness in short cycle contracts experienced this financial year. The impact of the step-downs on EBITA has been increased from c£50m to £63m (£13m).
Assuming EBITA in the middle of the guidance range would imply a £32.4m reduction (7%) to our FY20 estimates resulting in PBT of £475.5m (EPS 73.7p). Valuation. The shares (post forecast changes) trade on 6.9x FY2020E EPS and 5.4x FY2020E EBITDA, in aggregate a 30% discount to the FTSE All Share. Another downgrade to estimates in a long series of downgrades. It is currently difficult to envisage a catalyst to positively rerate shares, therefore despite the shares trading on only 6.9x FY20E EPS we lower our recommendation to Hold (from Add) with a revised target price of 461p (was 578p), which is based on a 35% discount to the FTSE All Share.

BE12:08pm

Conclusion: Encouraging signs from Food in Q4 and a 19/20 guidance consistent with broadly flat profits is offset by heavily diluting terms of the rights issue and hesitant C+H performance. 2020 P/E and FCY of 11x/10.8% pre Ocado are to be impacted by 20% of new shares issued at 185p. With last week’s news of Waitrose’s own accelerated online plans unhelpfully timed.
Details: M&S FY PBT £523m (JEFe/cons £519m), with Q4 trends revealing C+H LFL -1.3% (below JEFe/cons -0.4%/-1.1%) and Food at -1.5% inc Easter dilution (better than JEFe/cons -3.1%/-3.0%). Guidance for 19/20 gross margin (-25bps/+25bps in both C+H and Food) and costs (down by up to 1%) is consistent with cons for broadly unchanged earnings (pre Ocado funding). But with a H2 weighting to the delivery.
Capex guide of £350m/£400m after an uncharacteristically low £283m in 18/19 confirms no Big Bang approach to the democratisation of the food offering. Final DPS pre-announced at 7.1p and net debt at £1.55bn slightly ahead.

BE12:08pm

And RBC.

BE12:09pm

We think the focus today will be on the following areas:
1) Gross margin guidance for FY20 – M&S has guided to -25bps to +25bps for both Clothing & Home (vs our +20bps estimate), and for Food (versus our -20bps forecast). We see risks to the downside for Clothing from FY21 owing to the recent softer £ trend vs the USD.
2) Store restructuring plan – M&S has closed 35 stores and has 85 more to do, bringing the total to 120 versus initial expectations of c.100. In addition it will now close c.25 Simply Food stores. This is leading to downward pressure on space guidance (-3% for Clothing for FY20 and -1% for Food) and also on opex. Opex guidance for FY20 is up to -1% yoy versus our -1.1% yoy estimate.
3) Capex guidance – capex guidance of £350-400mn is ahead of our £350mn estimate. M&S' tax rate guidance of 23% higher than our 21% estimate.
4) Outlook statement – M&S is expecting some improvement in trading performance for both businesses in FY20, albeit this will be H2 weighted
as new ranges come through, particularly in Clothing and Home. Cash exceptional costs should be broadly in line with FY19 (c.£145mn). The introduction of IFRS 16 should be broadly neutral to PBT in FY20.

Tony Scott Red- Greed is Good has been ingrained in peoples minds
BE12:10pm

The fast pace of change continues and early actions are starting to bear fruit. The 4Q performance in Food is encouraging with volumes reacting to price investment and guidance for gross margin in FY20E better than expected. Other signs include even more store closures, clothing online market share increasing by 30bp, clothing range rationalization and the proportion of food on discount dropping by 10 percentage points. The rights issue and dividend cut are funding an exciting new chapter in the M&S investment case as well as supporting the balance sheet. With the overhang of the rights issue announcement out of the way it is time for investors to revisit M&S.
